page.title: International reactions to the 2011 Egyptian revolution

revisions.rev:
{{About|the international reactions to the 2011 Egyptian protests|the domestic responses|Domestic responses to the 2011 Egyptian revolution}} {{Cleanup|date=June 2011}} {{Use British English|date=April 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}}
'''International reactions to the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]]''' refer to external responses to the events that took place in Egypt between 25 January and 10 February 2011, as well as some of the events after the collapse of the government of [[President of Egypt|Egyptian President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]], such as Mubarak's trial. The reactions have generally been either measured or supportive of the [[Egyptian people]], with most governments and organisations calling for non-violent responses on both sides and peaceful moves towards reform. Whilst the protesters called for Mubarak to step down immediately,<ref>{{cite news|author=Al-Shalchi, Hadeel; El Deeb, Sarah|title=Mubarak Says He Will Not Seek Re-Election|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/1/massive-crowds-across-egypt-demand-mubaraks-ouster/?page=|accessdate=2 February 2011|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[The Washington Times]]'')|date=1 February 2011}}</ref> most foreign governments stopped short of this demand, at least during the early phases of the protests, due to [[realpolitik]] concerns about the consequences of a power vacuum on the stability of [[Egypt]] specifically and to the wider [[Middle East]] as a whole. Some Middle Eastern leaders expressed support for Mubarak. Meanwhile many governments issued [[travel advisory|travel advisories]] and evacuated their citizens from the country.
The protests captured worldwide attention in part due to the increasing use of [[Twitter]], [[Facebook]], [[YouTube]], and other [[social media|social-media]] platforms, which empowered activists and onlookers to communicate, coordinate, and document the events as they occur. Many countries experienced their own solidarity protests in support of the Egyptians. As the levels of meta-publicity increased, the Egyptian government stepped up [[Domestic responses to the 2011 Egyptian protests#Media censorship and circumvention|efforts to limit Internet access]], especially to social media. In response there has been [[hacktivism]], with global groups attempting to provide alternative communication methods for the Egyptians.
==Supranational bodies== * [[File:Flag African Union.svg|border|25px]][[African Union]] (AU) â The African Union urged Mubarak to respond to the mass protests with reforms. AU Peace and Security Commissioner [[Ramtane Lamamra]] called on Mubarak to bring in reforms in response to the unrest. "We believe that there are changes that are necessary in order to respond to the wishes of the people, economic reforms, social measures,and probably also issues related to the governement that need to be addressed."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jHuPin2AkxVSPT6qEgxgyjwPYj0w?docId=CNG.bc937a1a30aafcea92c02296ce113ff6.5d1|title=African Union Urges Egypt Reforms|publisher=''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (via ''[[Google News]]'')|last= Vesperini|first= Helen|date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Arab League}} â [[Amr Moussa]], the head of the Arab League, said he wanted to see a multi-party democracy emerge but did not say how soon. Speaking to the [[BBC]]'s ''[[The World This Weekend]]'', the former Egyptian Foreign Minister said that Mubarak needed to respond to the protests with actual reform, rather than just reshuffling ministers. "This new government should be just the beginning, just a new prime minister and new ministers does not necessarily mean a change, clear lines of policy will have to be declared."<ref>{{cite news|author=Weir, Keith|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70T0B620110130?sp=true|title=Arab League Head Wants Egypt Multi-Party Democracy|work=[[Reuters]]|date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|European Union}} â The European Union's foreign policy chief [[Catherine Ashton]] said Egyptian authorities should listen to their people, deal with their problems, and respect their right to demonstrate. She urged the "Egyptian authorities to respect and to protect the right of Egyptian citizens to manifest their political aspirations".<ref name="AP Protesters Clash">{{cite news|author=Hendawi, Hamza; Michael, Maggie|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_EGYPT_PROTEST?SITE=DCTMS&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|title=Egypt Protesters Clash for 2nd Day with Police|work=Associated Press|date=31 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|United Nations}} â [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|UN Secretary-General]] [[Ban Ki-moon]] said that world leaders should see the Egyptian protests as a chance to address "legitimate concerns" of the Egyptian people. He urged local authorities to refrain from violence. The [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]] [[Navi Pillay]] said that most of the frustration and angst has been caused by the emergency laws and urged the government to allow access to the Internet and mobile services. She said measures should be taken to guarantee rights of peaceful assembly and expression.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/162435.html |title=UN Warns Egypt of Rights Violations |work=[[Press TV]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
==Middle East== * {{flag|Iran}} â [[Supreme Leader of Iran|Iranian Supreme Leader]] [[Ayatollah Sayyed Ali Khamenei]], calling himself "your brother in religion" on 4 February, said that the unrest in Egypt was an "explosion of sacred anger" and an "Islamic awakening." He called Mubarak a "traitor dictator" who committed a "great betrayal" of his people by cooperating with Israel and the United States. Khamenei told Egyptians, "Do not believe in the game which is being played by the West and America; don't believe in their role, don't believe in their political manoeuvres which are taking place in the midst of your awakening. Just a few day ago...the Americans were supporting the corrupt regime, and now after they are sick of preserving him, they are speaking about the rights of the people. They are trying to replace one spy with another...Look with doubt â always be suspicious â regarding the American role and American intervention."<ref name="Khamenei">{{cite news| url=http://www.csmonitor.com/layout/set/print/content/view/print/361116|work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|title=Iran's Khamenei Praises Egyptian Protesters, Declares 'Islamic Awakening' â Ayatollah Sayyed Ali Khamenei, Iran's Supreme Religious Leader, Addressed Egypt's Protesters in Arabic on Friday, Calling President Mubarak a 'Traitor Dictator' Who Has Betrayed Egyptians|author=Peterson, Scott|date=4 February 2011|accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> He added that "America's control over Egypt's leaders has...turned Egypt into the biggest enemy of Palestine and turned it into the greatest refuge for Zionists. This explosion we see among the people of Egypt is the appropriate response to this great betrayal that the traitor dictator committed against his people."<ref>{{cite news | date=4 February 2011 | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/02/04/world/main7317510.shtml | title=Iran Leader: "Traitor" Mubarak Betrayed Egypt â Ayatollah Ali Khamenei Calls Uprising Against "Dictator" Appropriate, Compares Unrest to 1979 Iranian Revolution | publisher=[[CBS News]] | accessdate=5 February 2011 }}</ref> On 6 February, protesters in Cairo's Tahrir Square accused Iran of interfering in Egyptian affairs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/311143 |title=Thousands flock to Tahrir to honor protests' martyrs | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref> *: [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Iran|Iranian Foreign Minister]] [[Ali Akbar Salehi]] hoped that the Egyptians' "high aims, national demands and resurrection of their glory could be achieved in the very near future." [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Iran)|Iranian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] spokesman [[Ramin Mehmanparast]] called on Egypt to "abide by the rightful demands of the nation."<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Egypt Protests Draw Mixed Reaction in Region|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/29/egypt.middle.east.reaction/|work=[[CNN]]|date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> There were "solidarity" protests outside the Egyptian interests section.{{clarify|date=January 2011}}<!--which embassy?--> *: [[Islamic Consultative Assembly (Iran)|Iranian parliament speaker]] [[Ali Larijani]] said, "The voice of the brave people of Egypt is the voice of revolution. The start of this revolution has astonished the despotic regimes of the region. The parliament supports the uprising of the Tunisian and Egyptian people." He described the protests as "the revolution of the noble."<ref name="pakistantoday1">{{cite web|author=Name * |url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2011/01/iran-backs-egypts-revolution-of-the-noble/ |title=Iran backs Egypt's 'revolution of the noble' | Pakistan Today | Latest news, Breaking news, Pakistan News, World news, business, sport and multimedia |publisher=Pakistan Today |date=2011-01-30 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> Iran backed the protests. Parliament speaker [[Ali Larijani]] called the uprising the "revolution of the noble". He compared Western reaction to the protests with their reaction to the 1979 [[Islamic Revolution]].<ref name="pakistantoday1"/> ** [[Mir Hossein Mousavi]] and [[Mehdi Karroubi]], former presidential candidates and the leaders of the [[Iranian Green Movement|Green Movement]], released a statement from their virtual [[house arrest]] in Tehran, assuring the Egyptians, "No power can suppress the people's will and demand. Sooner or later, autocratic and tyrant power[s] are sentenced to vanish."<ref name="Khamenei"/> * {{flag|Iraq}} â Prime Minister [[Nouri al-Maliki]] stated, "The people have the right to express what they want without being persecuted... One of the characteristics of a lack of democracy is when a leader rules for 30 or 40 years. It is a difficult issue for people, it is intolerable and change is necessary."<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12373767 | title=Iraq PM Nouri Maliki 'will not seek third term' | publisher=BBC News | date=5 February 2011 }}</ref> *: The Iraqi Foreign Ministry wished Egypt and its citizens "progress and prosperity."<ref name="mofairaq"/> * {{flag|Israel}} â President [[Shimon Peres]] said Mubarak's "contribution to peace will never be forgotten. I thank him for saving many people's lives by preventing war. The biggest problem isn't changing the government but changing the face of a country as poor as Egypt." He added concerns about the Muslim Brotherhood: "Elections in Egypt are dangerous. Should the Muslim Brotherhood be elected they will not bring peace. Democracy without peace is not a democracy. We fear there will be a change in government without a change in the circumstances which led to this state."<ref>Efraim, Omri (5 February 2011). [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4024283,00.html "Peres Praises Mubarak for His Contribution to Peace â In Jerusalem Conference President thanks His Egyptian Counterpart for 'Saving Many People's Lives by Preventing War'; Expresses Concern over Possibility of Muslim Brotherhood's Rise to Power"]. ''[[Ynetnews]]''. Retrieved 6 February 2011.</ref> *: [[Prime Minister of Israel|Israeli Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] and the Israeli Foreign Ministry announced on 28 January that they are keeping a close track of the situation in neighbouring Egypt, but are refraining from taking a political stance. Ministers were told to refrain from commenting<ref name="time">Vick, Karl (30 January 2011). [http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2045166,00.html "As Egypt's Crisis Grows, So Do the Anxieties in Israel"]. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref> due to the sensitive nature of [[Egypt-Israel relations|relations]]. *: Foreign Minister [[Avigdor Lieberman]] told European diplomats at the [[Knesset]] that the root cause of the unrest was internal problems. "Whoever thinks that the Palestinian-Israeli conflict is part of the problems in the Middle East is trying to escape reality. [The] big picture of the Middle East shows that major points of contention stem from challenges and confrontations within Islamic society. The Arab world is becoming increasingly weakened. At the end of the day, it is clear to everyone, even to the [[Palestinian Authority]], that the greatest danger they are facing is not Zionism, but rather Hamas and Jihad."<ref>{{cite web|last=Lis |first=Jonathan |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/lieberman-mideast-uprisings-show-the-arab-world-is-weakening-1.341859 |title=Lieberman: Mideast uprisings show the Arab world is weakening â Haaretz Daily Newspaper | Israel News |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=7 November 2010 |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> During the early days of the protests, the Foreign Ministry was receiving updates every few hours and Lieberman was in close contact with the Israeli ambassador to Egypt, Yitzhak Levanon.<ref>{{cite web|author=Ravid, Barak (with news agencies)|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/pm-netanyahu-israel-will-monitor-but-not-comment-on-egypt-protests-1.339895 |title=PM Netanyahu: Israel Will Monitor But Not Comment on Egypt Protests â The Foreign Ministry Is Conducting Status Updates on Egypt Every Couple of Hours and Foreign Minister Avigdor Lieberman Has Been Maintaining Close Contact with Israel's Ambassador to Egypt|work=[[Haaretz]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The Ministry was concerned over "substantial" changes in the regime.<ref name="israel evacuation">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.qassam.ps/news-4112-Israel_expresses_concern_as_protesters_continued.html |title=Israel Expresses Concern as Protesters Continued |publisher=[[Izz ad-Din al-Qassam Brigades]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The [[Associated Press]] reported that security officials anonymously expressed concern that the violence could threaten ties with Egypt, and spread to the [[Palestinian Authority]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Federman |first=Josef |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/jan/29/israel-watches-egypt-uprising-fear/ |title=Israel watches Egypt uprising with fear |publisher=Washington Times |date=2011-01-29 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> The government was said to be pressuring the US to postpone a plan for Mubarak's departure so that it could prepare for any likely outcome.<ref name="bloombergreactions"/> ** [[Binyamin Ben-Eliezer]], a [[Labor Party of Israel|Labor]] member of the Knesset (MK), said that "all we can do is express our" support for Mubarak and hope the riots pass quietly.<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Ben-Eliezer: All We Can Do Is Express Support for Mubarak |url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=205362 |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> He said Mubarak "had very tough things to say about the United States. [Mubarak] gave me a lesson in democracy and said: 'We see the democracy the United States spearheaded in Iran and with Hamas, in Gaza, and that's the fate of the Middle East. They may be talking about democracy but they don't know what they're talking about and the result will be extremism and radical Islam.'" According to him Mubarak realised "it was the end of the Mubarak era."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/11/us-egypt-israel-mubarak-idUSTRE71A64V20110211 |title=Mubarak slammed U.S. in phone call with Israeli lawmaker |publisher=Reuters |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref> ** MK [[Ibrahim Sarsur]], who leads the [[United Arab List]], expressed "full support for the protesters in Egypt. The Arab [[police state]]s have given their peoples no other option but to take to the streets for a peopleâs revolution to topple the suppressing regimes and to free themselves from the control of dictators."<ref>{{cite news |author=Gedalyahu, Tzvi Ben|title=Israeli Arab MK Joins Iran and Jordan Islamists To Back Protests|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/142014|work=[[Arutz Sheva]]|date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> ** Former ambassador to Egypt Eli Shaked said that "there can be no doubt that the new regime will seek to deal the peace with Israel a very public blow. The only people in Egypt who are committed to peace are the people in Mubarak's inner circle."<ref name="time"/> * {{flag|Jordan}} â Jordan's King [[Abdullah II]] "wished the brotherly country of Egypt security, stability and progress."<ref name="haaretz1">{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/obama-future-egypt-gov-t-must-respect-the-will-of-the-people-1.340220 |title=Obama: Future Egypt Gov't Must Respect the Will of the People â U.S. President Reiterates Importance of Universal Rights in Phone Conversations with Netanyahu, Turkey PM Erdogan, Jordan's Abdullah, and UK Premier Cameron |work=[[Haaretz]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref><ref> [http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011211162849852442.html World reacts as Mubarak steps down] ''[[Al-Jazeera English]]''. 11 February 2011.</ref> * {{flag|Kuwait}} â Kuwait's Emir [[Sabah Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah]] condemned the riots and affirmed Kuwait 's support to the Egyptian government and people. In a phone call to Mubarak, Sheikh Sabah expressed the State of Kuwait's condemnation of all acts of "riots, looting and sabotage" that terrified the citizens and undermined the security and stability of Egypt. Sheikh Sabah said he was confident the "Egyptian brothers" would overcome this "critical" phase to reach security and stability.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.da.gov.kw/eng/newsroom/latestNews.php#4264 |title=Welcome to the official website of Al-Diwan Al-Amiri |publisher=Da.gov.kw |date=26 January 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Lebanon}} â [[Hezbollah]] [[Secretary-General]] [[Hassan Nasrallah]] said he supports the rights of the protesters, while he condemned external influences.{{citation needed|date=February 2011}} He praised the struggle, saying victory would "entirely change the face of our region for the interest of its own people, especially in Palestine. The US came to bring down this regime, which was a faithful friend in ensuring US interests. If we listen to the Americans from both parties â [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] and [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] â does it make sense that the US would try to bring down [Mubarak] as we saw in the [[Islamic revolution|1979 revolution]] in Iran? The Americans are riding the wave, trying to contain the uprising while attempting to improve their loathsome image in our world and present themselves as protectors of nations and their freedoms after decades where they got into bed with the worst dictators in the region. The US government carried out surveys in our region in order to see what people think, what they want and what they don't want. The answers were clear. The overwhelming majority is hostile towards the US policy and rejects it for its absolute slant towards Israel."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4025270,00.html |title=Nasrallah: Egypt win to change region â Israel News, Ynetnews |publisher=Ynetnews.com |date=20 June 1995 |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> He called out Israel for "putting pressure on every political circle in the world to protect Mubarak's regime"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/164239.html |title=PressTV â Nasrallah exposes Israel's Egypt plot |publisher=Presstv.ir |date= |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> and stated that the "protests will push out [the] regime that has maintained peace with Israel."<ref>{{cite web|last=Wertheimer |first=Stef |url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=207203 |title=Nasrallah: Unrest in Egypt will transform Middle East |publisher=Jpost.com |date= |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> His comments were rebuked by the Egyptian Foreign Ministry, which said that he is "walking in the footsteps of his mentor", a reference to Khameini. It accused both leaders of wanting "to ignite the region."<ref>{{cite web|last=Wertheimer |first=Stef |url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=207456 |title=Egypt: Hizbullah and Iran want to 'ignite the region' |publisher=Jpost.com |date= |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Libyan Arab Jamahiriya}} â [[List of heads of state of Libya|Libyan Leader]] [[Muammar al-Gaddafi]], during a telephone conversation with Mubarak, expressed confidence in the stability of Egyptian society and preserving the gains Egypt has achieved. He expressed his wishes for the completion of Egypt's march towards the greater good and progress for its people and to continue its central role in the defence of issues of the nation.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{Clarify|date=January 2011|reason=needs byline (or in absence of byline "staff writer" dropped into "author" field).}} {{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/D3BDB84E-3148-4B5E-B813-69667F22A4F3.htm|title=Ø¯Ø¹Ù Ø¹Ø§ÙÙ Ù ÙØ­Ù Ø§ÙØªØ¸Ø§ÙØ± Ø¨Ù ØµØ±|trans_title=''Global Support for Right To Protest in Egypt''|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=27 January 2011|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> On 23 July, months after the revolution and amidst a widespread [[2011 Libyan civil war|uprising]] in his own country, Gaddafi criticized the revolutionaries in an audio address: "After you looted, destroyed and damaged the country, you want a new president?" He said Mubarak "should be honored" and that he should not have been removed from power and suggested the revolution was meaningless.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE76N01D20110724|date=24 July 2011|accessdate=24 July 2011|title=Gaddafi criticises Egyptian, Tunisian revolutions|agency=Reuters}}</ref> * {{flag|Palestine}} â [[Palestinian National Authority]] President [[Mahmoud Abbas]] telephoned Mubarak to express his support.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=205766|title=Abbas Calls Mubarak To Express Support|author=Toameh, Khaled Abu|date=29 January 2011|work=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> ** [[Hamas]] said the border with Egypt was calm. The border was closed.<ref>{{cite web | date=30 January 2011 | url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Gaza-shuts-border-with-Egypt-as-unrest-spirals/Article1-656399.aspx | title=Gaza Shuts Border with Egypt as Unrest Spirals | publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] (via [[Hindustan Times]]) | accessdate=31 January 2011 }}</ref> *** The Gaza-Egypt [[Rafah]] border crossing was also closed during the protests.<ref>{{cite web | author=[[Staff writer]] | date=2 February 2011 | url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/travel-advice-by-country/middle-east-north-africa/egypt/ | title=Middle East and North Africa â Egypt | publisher=[[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]] | accessdate=2 February 2011 }}</ref> On 9 February continuing protests in Egypt threatened the supply of petrol into the [[Gaza strip]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/02/201129133520872347.html |title=Egypt events spark Gaza fuel panic â Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> ** The [[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine]] (PFLP) declared its solidarity with the protesters and called for [[social revolution|social]] and [[political revolution]] in Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.pflp.ps/english/?q=comrade-maqdesi-salutes-egyptian-people-and-their- |title=Comrade Maqdesi Salutes the Egyptian People and Their Struggle|publisher=[[Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine]] |date=undated |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Saudi Arabia}} â [[King of Saudi Arabia|Saudi King]] [[Abdullah of Saudi Arabia|Abdullah Bin Abdul-Aziz]] expressed support for Mubarak. "No Arab or Muslim can tolerate any meddling in the security and stability of Arab and Muslim Egypt by those who infiltrated the people in the name of freedom of expression, exploiting it to inject their destructive hatred. As they condemn this, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and its people and government declares it stands with all its resources with the government of Egypt and its people."<ref>{{cite news|author=Aboudi, Sami; Fuchsurl, Martina|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/egypt-saudi-idAFLDE70S08V20110129 |title=Update 1 â Saudi King Expresses Support for Mubarak |work=[[Reuters]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> He condemned the "people who tried to destabilise the security and stability of Egypt."<ref>{{Clarify|date=January 2011|reason=needs byline (or in absence of byline "staff writer" dropped into the "author" field).}} {{cite news|url=http://arabic.cnn.com/2011/egypt.2011/1/29/arab.egypt_rex/index.html|title=Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ³Ø¹ÙØ¯Ù" ÙØ¯Ø¹Ù Ù Ø¨Ø§Ø±Ù ÙÙØ¯ÙÙ "Ø§ÙÙ ÙØ¯Ø³ÙÙ|trans_title=''Saudi King Shows His Support for Mubarak, Condemns 'the Infiltrators'<nowiki></nowiki>''|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=29 January 2011|work=[[CNN]]|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
==Americas== * {{flag|Brazil}} â On 31 January [[President of Brazil|President]] [[Dilma Rousseff]] said, "[Brazil] hopes that Egypt becomes a democracy, leading its people to benefit from [Egyptian] development."<ref>{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=headline in portuguese. at minimum, needs english translation of headline appended in "[ ]" next to porteugese headline }} [[Staff writer]] (31 January 2011). [http://noticias.uol.com.br/ultimas-noticias/internacional/2011/01/31/brasil-torce-para-que-egito-seja-um-pais-democratico-diz-dilma.jhtm "Brasil torce para que Egito seja um paÃ­s democrÃ¡tico, diz Dilma"] (in [[Portuguese language|Portguese]]). ''[[Universo Online|UOL NotÃ­cias]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref> *: The [[Ministry of External Relations (Brazil)|Ministry of External Relations]] issued a statement on 1 February calling for a "political evolution that meets the expectations of their people in a peaceful environment, bereft of foreign interference, so as to foster the ongoing economic and social development" and pointed out that "Egypt is an important [[Mercosur]] partner".<ref name="MRE">{{cite press release | date=28 January 2011 | url=http://www.itamaraty.gov.br/sala-de-imprensa/notas-a-imprensa/situacao-no-egito-na-tunisia-e-no-iemen | title=Situation in Egypt, Tunisia and Yemen | publisher=[[Ministry of External Relations (Brazil)|Brazilian Ministry of External Relations]] | accessdate= 3 February 2011 }}</ref> The arrest of two Brazilian journalists in Cairo on 2 February prompted the Ministry of External Relations to raise its tone in remarks about the political crisis in Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.estadao.com.br/noticias/internacional,apos-prisao-de-jornalistas-no-egito-itamaraty-eleva-tom,674951,0.htm |title=ApÃ³s prisÃ£o de jornalistas no Egito, Itamaraty eleva tom ("After the Arrest of Journalists in Egypt, Foreign Ministry Raises Tone") (in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]) |publisher=Estadao.com.br |date= |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> it "deplore[d] the violent clashes [and] denounce[d] the arrests of Brazilian journalists Corban Costa, from [[RÃ¡dio Nacional]], and Gilvan Rocha, from [[TV Brasil]], and expects that Egyptian authorities take the appropriate measures to uphold the civil liberties and to protect the population at large and the foreigners on the ground from bodily harm."<ref>[[Press release]] (3 February 2011). [http://www.itamaraty.gov.br/sala-de-imprensa/notas-a-imprensa/situacao-no-egito-1 "Situation in Egypt"]. [[Ministry of External Relations (Brazil)|Brazilian Ministry of External Relations]]. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref> [[File:Obama calls Mubarak Oval Office Jan 2011.jpg|thumb|U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] speaks on the phone with Mubarak during the protests]] {{quote box|width=216px|quote="Violence will not address the grievances of the Egyptian people, and suppressing ideas never succeeds in making them go away.... Around the world governments have an obligation to respond to their citizens.... All governments must maintain power through consent, not coercion. That is the single standard by which the people of Egypt will achieve the future they deserve."|source=â Barack Obama<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2011-01-29-obama-egypt_N.htm |title=Obama admonishes Egypt's Mubarak on protests |publisher=Usatoday.Com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110129/ap_on_re_us/us_us_egypt |title=Obama calls for restraint, reform in Egypt â Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=88942&st=&st1=|title=Remarks on the Situation in Egypt|publisher=John T. Woolley and Gerhard Peters, The American Presidency Project [online]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 29 January 2011}}</ref>}} * {{flag|Canada}} â [[Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister]] [[Lawrence Cannon]] said that Egypt remains an [[Canada-Egypt relations|important partner]] for Canada and urged "the Egyptian government to ensure full freedom of political expression for its citizens." He said the Canadian government "continues to stand by the people of Egypt as they demand democratic reforms and respect for human rights. We urge the Government of Egypt to begin an immediate transition toward serious democratic reform."<ref>(2 February 2011). [http://www.international.gc.ca/media/aff/news-communiques/2011/044.aspx?lang=eng "Minister Cannon Condemns Violence in Egypt"]. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref> * {{flag|Chile}} â A press release from the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Chile)|Chilean Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] declared that it is "permanently following the evolution of the events".<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=headline in spanish. at minimum, needs english translation of spanish headline appended in "trans_title" field}} {{cite news|title=Egipto: comunicado de prensa de CancillerÃ­a|url=http://www.minrel.gov.cl/prontus_minrel/site/artic/20110131/pags/20110131091403.php|trans_title=|language=[[Spanish language|Spanish]]|work=[[MINREL]]|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=31 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Colombia}} â [[President of Colombia|Colombian President]] [[Juan Manuel Santos]] asked Mubarak to ensure the situation returns to normal. He said that "[the Colombian people] moves along with the Egyptian people in search of their welfare, freedom and plain use of their human rights and trusts that Mubarak and his government would promote in a short term the return to calm and the strengthening of the democratic institutions." He told their embassy to be prepared to assist Colombian citizens in Egypt.<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=headline in spanish. at minimum, needs english translation of spanish headline appended next to spanish headline}} [[Staff writer]] (31 January 2011). [http://www.eltiempo.com/politica/santos-pide-a-presidente-egipcio-fortalecer-instituciones-democraticas_8809619-4 "Santos pide a presidente egipcio fortalecer instituciones democrÃ¡ticas"] (in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]). ''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (via ''[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]]''). Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref> * {{flag|Cuba}} â [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Cuba)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Bruno RodrÃ­guez Parrilla]] hoped for a positive outcome to the protests as one that "meets the interests of the Egyptian people and nation (''[[sic]]'')."<ref>(3 February 2011). [http://www.cubaminrex.cu/english/Actualidad/2011/enero/Cuba%20rejects.html Cuba Rejects U.S. Meddling in Egypt"]. Foreign Affairs of Cuba. Retrieved 5 February 2011.</ref> * {{flag|United States}} â [[President of the United States|US President]] [[Barack Obama]], noting that he had spoken with the Egyptian president, stated that his first concern is preventing injury or loss of life. He remarked, "What's needed right now are concrete steps that advance the rights of the Egyptian people...Ultimately the future of Egypt will be determined by the Egyptian people. The United States will always be a committed partner to that future, with the Egyptian government, and with the Egyptian people." He recalled that in his [[A New Beginning|speech in Cairo]] in June 2009 he had stated, "All governments must maintain power through consent, not coercion," and called upon the Egyptian government to restore its people's access to the internet. He called on all parties to refrain from violence in their efforts to bring about a solution.<ref name="Barack Obama">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/jan/28/egypt-protests-live-updates|title=Egypt Protests Live Updates|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011|location=London|first1=Matthew|last1=Weaver|first2=Haroon|last2=Siddique|first3=Richard|last3=Adams|first4=Tim|last4=Hill}}</ref> He said that the Egyptian protesters have "universal" rights, including the right to peaceful assembly and association, free speech, and âthe ability to determine their own destiny. [...] These are human rights and the United States will stand up for them everywhere."<ref>{{cite web|last=Johnston |first=Nicholas |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/obama-says-mubarak-must-take-concrete-steps-to-deliver-pledge-on-reforms.html |title=Obama Tells Mubarak He Must Stick to Pledge of Democratic Reforms in Egypt |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> White House spokesman [[Robert Gibbs]] expressed anger at the pace of change in Egypt, saying the transition should happen quickly, which he also said would determine US aid to the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/politics/2011/02/us-angered-over-egypt-hopeful-over-yemen-jordan |title=US angered over Egypt, hopeful over Yemen, Jordan | The Associated Press | Politics |publisher=Washington Examiner |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> Gibbs posted a statement on [[Twitter]] expressing concern "about violence in Egypt", adding the "government must respect the rights of the Egyptian people & turn on social networking and the internet".<ref name="Twitter">{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/PressSec/status/31026478648926208|title=Gibbs on Twitter|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011}}</ref> *: [[Vice President of the United States|US Vice President]] [[Joseph Biden]] said Hosni Mubarak "has been an ally of ours in a number of things. And heâs been very responsible on, relative to geopolitical interest in the region, the Middle East peace efforts: the actions Egypt has taken relative to normalising relationship with Israel."<ref name="Joe Biden">{{cite news|last=Murphy|first=Dan|url=http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/2011/01/exclusive-biden-discusses-unrest-in-egypt-keeping-us-competitive.html|title=Exclusive: Biden Discusses Unrest in Egypt, Keeping U.S. Competitive|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service]]|date=26 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011}}</ref> *: [[United States Secretary of State|US Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] said, "The Egyptian government has an important opportunity to be responsive to the aspirations of the Egyptian people, and pursue political, economic and social reforms that can improve their lives and help Egypt prosper."<ref name="Clinton">{{cite web|author=Awad, Marwa; Dziadoszurl, Alexander|url=http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/wrni/news.newsmain/article/0/0/1754229/.World./Egypt's.Mubarak.faces.unprecedented.protests|title=Egypt's Mubarak Faces Unprecedented Protests|publisher=''[[Reuters]]'' (via ''[[WRNI]]'')|date=25 January 2011|accessdate= 31 January 2011}}</ref> She told ''Al Jazeera'' that Mubarak has been an ally of the US in the past because he has maintained the [[EgyptâIsrael Peace Treaty|peace treaty]] with Israel in maintaining stability.<!--from tv-->{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} She said the US supports an "orderly transition."<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011130164532649572.html |title=''Al Jazeera'' Undeterred by Egypt Curb â Will Continue Its Comprehensive Coverage of Landmark Events There, Says Network Chief|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> On 8 March Clinton said Egypt's transition to democracy would be incomplete if women were not equal partners with men in creating the new society. She criticised the lack of women involved in efforts to draft a new constitution, saying in part, "The women in Egypt and [[Tunisia]] and other nations have just as much right as the men to remake their governments â to make them responsive, accountable, transparent."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/08/clinton-women-middle-east-international-womens-day_n_832974.html|date=8 March 2011|accessdate=9 March 2011|agency=The Huffington Post|title=Clinton: Women Must Get Role In Middle East Transition}}</ref> *: On 26 January [[United States Ambassador to Egypt|US Ambassador to Egypt]] [[Margaret Scobey]] commented, "we call on the Egyptian authorities to allow peaceful public demonstrations".<ref name="Dan Murphy 0126">{{cite news|last=Murphy|first=Dan|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2011/0126/The-US-response-to-Egypt-s-protests|title=The US Response to Egypt's Protests â 'Not Much' Probably Sums It Up Best|work=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date=26 January 2011|accessdate= 31 January 2011}}</ref> *: [[Frank G. Wisner]], a former United States ambassador to Egypt, was appointed{{when|date=February 2011|reason=needs context}} a [[special envoy]] to Egypt during the protests.<ref>Weaver, Michael; Siddique, Haroon; Adams, Richard (31 January 2011). [http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/jan/31/egypt-protests-live-updates "Egypt Protests â Monday 31 January"]. ''News Blog'' of ''[[The Guardian]]''. Retrieved 5 February 2011.</ref> On 5 February, he said that it is important for Mubarak stay in power for now in order to ease a transition to democracy. He said the [[constitution of Egypt]] calls for an election to be held within two months of Mubarak's resignation, and implied that this would not be sufficient time for pro-democracy forces to make themselves known to the Egyptian people.<ref>{{registration required|date=February 2011}} [http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2011/02/05/world/europe/AP-EU-Germany-Security-Conference.html?_r=1&ref=news "US Envoy: Mubarak Has to Lead Egypt to Transition"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. 5 February 2011.</ref> ** [[NASA]] gave Essam Mohamed Haji, a research scientist at the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]], permission to write the name of Sally Zahran, who was beaten to death at Tahrir Square, on a spacecraft headed to Mars.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/314995 |title=NASA to honor Tahrir Square martyr by putting name on spacecraft | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Venezuela}} â [[President of Venezuela|President]] [[Hugo Chavez]] spoke with his Syrian and Libyan counterparts, [[Bashar al-Assad]] and Muammar Gaddafi, about the political crisis. He told them that Venezuela backs a "peaceful solution." He said he "trust[s] that the situation will find on its own the road to harmony, justice and wellbeing."<ref>[[Staff writer]] (31 January 2011). [http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/world/egyptian-police-clash-with-opposition-protesters-in-cairo/story-e6freoox-1225996446437 "Egypt Protests: 'Change Is Coming'"]. ''[[The Courier-Mail]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref>
==Africa== * {{flag|Nigeria}} â The [[National Conscience Party]] chairman Femi Falana asked Mubarak to resign. "We welcome the unfolding revolution and the demonstration of peoplesâ power against bad governance, corruption, poverty, and oppression...We strongly condemn the violence and repression by the Mubarak-led government...Violence against Egyptians should stop. President Mubarak must resign now, and listen to the voices of millions of Egyptians who are demanding a change for a better future. Using excessive force to crackdown on peaceful protests and torturing protesters are grave breaches of international human rights law, and the African Union must publicly condemn the practice. The AU must side with the Egyptian people if it is to show that it is completely different from the defunct Organization of African Unity, whose sole purpose was to defend African dictators and not the African peoples."<ref>{{cite news |author= |title= Egypt: Nigeria's National Conscience Party Asks Mubarak To Resign|url= http://www.saharareporters.com/news-page/egypt-nigeria%E2%80%99s-national-conscience-party-asks-mubarak-resign |date= 30 January 2010 |accessdate= 4 February 2010 |publisher=Sahara reporters}}</ref> * {{flag|South Africa}} â On 4 February, the ''[[Mail & Guardian]]'' reported that [[Ayanda Ntsaluba]], the director general of international relations and cooperation, had said that the [[Government of South Africa|South African government]] had called for Mubarak to step down.<ref>{{cite news |author= Rossouw, Mandy |title= SA Calls for Mubarak To Step Down |url= http://www.mg.co.za/article/2011-02-04-sa-calls-for-mubarak-to-step-down |date= 4 February 2011 |accessdate= 4 February 2011 |work=[[Mail & Guardian]]}}</ref>
==Asia== * {{flag|People's Republic of China}} â Foreign Ministry spokesman Hong Lei stated "Egypt is a friendly country towards China. China follows the situation in Egypt and hopes it will maintain social stability and normal order" at a 27 January press conference.<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Transcript (law)|Transcript]]|title=Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Hong Lei's Regular Press Conference on January 27, 2011 |url=http://www.fmprc.gov.cn/eng/xwfw/s2510/t790683.htm |publisher=Office of [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> ''Al Jazeera'' reported that the Chinese government blocked searches of "Egypt" from its most-popular microblogging website, and restricted coverage of the Egyptian protests in the state media.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2011/01/201112991712140318.html |title=Egypt Not Trending in China â Beijing Blocks Searches for "Egypt" from Microblogging Site Following Protests There |work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> Bloggers in China, however, have disproved this.<ref>{{Verify credibility|date=January 2011|reason=this appears to be user-generated site. is source the underlying article (from al jazeera english)? or comments left on "reddit.com"? surely, mainstream media (al jazeera, nytimes, cnn, the guardian) has reported on this.}} {{cite web|url=http://www.reddit.com/r/worldnews/comments/fba0y/china_blocks_all_information_about_egypt |title=China Blocks All Information about Egypt|publisher=[[Reddit]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Verify credibility|date=January 2011|reason=this appears to be user-generated. what's to stop anyone from anywhere in world to post this? surely this topic was covered in mainstream press (nytimes, cnn, the guardian, al jazeera)?}} {{cite web|url=http://i55.tinypic.com/4kxsp5.png |title=Image of Chinese Search for Egypt |date= |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|India}} â Joint secretary and spokesperson of the [[Ministry of External Affairs (India)|Ministry of External Affairs]] Vishnu Prakash said, "We are closely following with concern the developments in Egypt. India has traditionally enjoyed close and friendly relations with Egypt. We hope for an early and peaceful resolution of the situation without further violence and loss of lives."<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Govt-airlifts-300-Indians-as-Egypt-crisis-worsens/articleshow/7393868.cms|title=Govt Airlifts 300 Indians as Egypt Crisis Worsens|work=[[The Times of India]]|date=31 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> On 1 February the Indian Ministry of External Affairs termed the mass protests in Egypt "an articulation of the aspirations of the Egyptian people for reform" and hoped for a peaceful resolution of the situation "in the best interests of the people of Egypt".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://meaindia.nic.in/mystart.php?id=530217128 |title=MEA â Ministry of External Affairs |publisher=Meaindia.nic.in |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Japan}} â [[Prime Minister of Japan|Japanese Prime Minister]] [[Naoto Kan]] urged Mubarak to start a dialogue with his people. "I hope the regime of Egypt will restore security and peace."<ref name="test">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.directory9.net/egypt-turmoil-shakes-wef-in-davos/ |title=Egypt Turmoil Shakes WEF in Davos |publisher=''[[News Directory]]'' (directory9.net)|date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> Foreign Minister [[Seiji Maehara]] urged the Egyptian government to resolve the ongoing political unrest peacefully. "Japan strongly hopes the Egyptian government and the people restrain violent action and create a stable government through dialogue."<ref name=autogenerated2>[http://en.rian.ru/world/20110130/162376166.html].</ref> * {{flag|Pakistan}} â Pakistan's foreign office spokesman Abdul Basit said that Pakistan is watching events in Egypt closely and is taking steps about the safety of [[Pakistanis in Egypt|700 families in Egypt]].<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|title=We Are Watching Events in Egypt Closely â FO|url=http://www.kalam.tv/ur/video/61756/index.html|work=[[Kalam TV]]|date=undated|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Philippines}} â Philippine Deputy Presidential spokesperson Abigail Valte called for a peaceful end to the strife in Egypt. Valte said the Philippine government was particularly concerned about the safety of the more than 6,500 Filipinos in Egypt. "We hope for a peaceful and just resolution to the political unrest currently taking place and the swift return to stability. We are monitoring the situation and our embassy in Cairo has contingencies in place and is prepared to relocate our citizens to safer areas. As always, the safety of our citizens is the paramount concern and we are doing what we can to anticipate and address their needs."<ref>{{cite web|author=Bordadora, Norman|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/breakingnews/nation/view/20110129-317309/Palace-calls-for-peaceful-end-to-strife-in-Egypt |title=Palace Calls for Peaceful End to Strife in Egypt |work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Sri Lanka}} â On 15 February the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Sri Lanka)|Sri Lankan Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] cautiously welcomed the political changes in a statement: "[[Sri Lanka]] and Egypt enjoy warm and close ties. It is in this context that Sri Lanka wishes for the people of Egypt progress and stability within a democratic framework of governance,"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.in.msn.com/international/article.aspx?cp-documentid=4924707 |title=In delayed reaction, Sri Lanka welcomes Egypt transition â International News â News â MSN India |publisher=News.in.msn.com |date=16 February 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref> and "The government of Sri Lanka welcomes the smooth and peaceful transition of power in Egypt".<ref>{{cite web|title=Sri Lanka cautiously welcomes transition of power in Egypt|url=http://www.colombopage.com/archive_11/Feb16_1297794860CH.php|publisher=ColomboPage|accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref> *{{ROC}} - the President of the Republic of China [[Ma Ying-jeou]] "hopes to see the rapid establishment of democracy in Egypt in accordance with the peopleâs will", according to Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang. Also, according to the director of Department of African Affairs of the ROC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs Samuel Chen, the Republic of China welcomes the coming of democracy in Egypt and hopes to "enhance bilateral exchanges." <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.taiwantoday.tw/ct.asp?xItem=150526&CtNode=420}}</ref>
==Europe== <!--3 February 2011- contrary to norm, put temporary spacers between countries for easier editing; can be removed after article is more finessed--> * {{flag|Austria}} â On 3 February [[Foreign Minister of Austria|Austrian Foreign Minister]] [[Michael Spindelegger]] condemned the violence. "It is more necessary than ever for talks to be started without delay between the opposition and the government in order to prevent the situation from getting further out of control. This also entails calling those responsible for acts of violence to account, and swiftly."<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Press release]]|url=http://www.bmeia.gv.at/en/foreign-ministry/news/presseaussendungen/2011/spindelegger-zu-aegypten-demonstrationen-koennen-nicht-durch-gewalt-mundtot-gemacht-werden.html|title=Spindelegger on Egypt: 'Demonstrations Cannot be Silenced by Violence' â Foreign Minister Very Concerned About Developments in Egypt and Calls for Renunciation of Force|publisher=[[Foreign Ministry of Austria|Austrian Foreign Ministry]]|date= 3 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Belarus}} â [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Belarus)|Belarussian Foreign Ministry]] Press Secretary Andrei Savinykh declared:{{when|date=February 2011}} "We are convinced that street clashes and violence is a bad way to solve pressing social and community issues. We urge the parties to solve existing problems peacefully in line with international legal norms ''[at]'' a negotiating table."<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Press release]]|url=http://www.mfa.gov.by/press/news_mfa/aea7305de456e29d.html |title=ÐÐ¾Ð¼Ð¼ÐµÐ½ÑÐ°ÑÐ¸Ð¹ Ð½Ð°ÑÐ°Ð»ÑÐ½Ð¸ÐºÐ° ÑÐ¿ÑÐ°Ð²Ð»ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ Ð¸Ð½ÑÐ¾ÑÐ¼Ð°ÑÐ¸Ð¸ â Ð¿ÑÐµÑÑ-ÑÐµÐºÑÐµÑÐ°ÑÑ ÐÐÐ ÐÐ½Ð´ÑÐµÑ Ð¡Ð°Ð²Ð¸Ð½ÑÑ Ð² ÑÐ²ÑÐ·Ð¸ Ñ ÑÐ¸ÑÑÐ°ÑÐ¸ÐµÐ¹ Ð² ÐÐ³Ð¸Ð¿ÑÐµ|trans_title=The comment on the situation in Egypt from Andrey Savinykh, the Head of Informational Department and Press Secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs|language=[[Russian language|Russian]]|publisher=[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Belarus)|Belarussian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]]|date= |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Belgium}} â In a statement released on 27 January, Belgian Deputy Prime Minister, Foreign Minister [[Steven Vanackere]] and Minister of Civil Service, Public Enterprises and Institutional Reforms deplored the deaths. He hopes that the protest will strengthen the process of democratisation and socio-economic reform in Egypt. He pointed out the importance of freedom of speech and media.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Press release]]|url=http://diplomatie.belgium.be/en/newsroom/news/press_releases/foreign_affairs/2011/01/ni_270111_vanackere_betogingen_egypte.jsp |title=Steven Vanackere on the Situation in Egypt |publisher=[[FPS Foreign Affairs Belgium|FPS Foreign Affairs, Foreign Trade and Development Cooperation]] |date=27 January 2011 |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Bulgaria}} â The Foreign Ministry condemned the violent response to the protests, and expressed condolences for the deaths.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.bg/en/news/view/30752|title=The events of last week demonstrate the need for serious social and economic reforms that can guarantee democracy and human rights in Egypt.|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Bulgaria|date= 30 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Croatia}} â [[Mario Dragun]], spokesman of the Croatian Foreign Ministry, said: "We hope that the violence will cease and democratic dialogue will ensue so that the crisis could be resolved and the political, economic and social reforms carried out with full respect for the basic human."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mvpei.hr/custompages/static/hrv/templates/_frt_Priopcenja_en.asp?id=6565|title=Croatia eyes events in Egypt with concern|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Croatia|date= 1 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> {{quote box|width=215px|quote="He is finished as Egypt's leader.
