authorities and protestors avoid the use of violence." Estonia urged their citizens in Egypt to leave the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vm.ee/?q=en/node/10709&ref=avaflash |title=Foreign Ministry Recommends Avoiding Travel to Egypt |publisher=Vm.ee |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Finland}} â [[Minister for Foreign Affairs (Finland)|Minister for Foreign Affairs]] [[Alexander Stubb]] called his counterpart [[Foreign Minister of Egypt]] [[Ahmed Aboul Gheit]] to express Finland's strong hopes that the conflict would be resolved peacefully. In a statement on the Finnish foreign ministry's website Stubb said, "Everyone should now strive to steady the situation quickly so that there would be no further fatalities or injuries. Finland condemns the use of force." He expressed concern over the blocking of communications.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://formin.finland.fi/Public/default.aspx?contentid=211714&nodeid=15145&culture=en-US |title=Statement on the situation in Egypt by Foreign Minister Alexander Stubb â Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland: Current affairs |publisher=Formin.finland.fi |date= |accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> [[File:Egypt solidarity protest in Paris, 29 January 2011 007.jpg|thumb|Solidarity protest near the Embassy of Egypt in Paris, 29 January 2011.]] * {{flag|France}} â Prime Minister [[Francois Fillon]]'s office said that France would be ceasing arms and tear gas sales to Egypt.<ref>{{cite news|author=By the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/europe/02/06/france.egypt.arms/ |title=France suspends arms sales to Egypt â CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date= 6 February 2011|accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref> Controversy arose over Fillon's links to the Mubarak regime, as he admitted having been a guest of Mubarak over the Christmas holiday at Egypt's expense.<ref>{{cite news|author=Kim Willsher in Paris |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/08/france-francois-fillon-christmas-egypt-mubarak |title=France's prime minister spent family Christmas break as guest of Mubarak | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= 8 February 2011|accessdate=8 February 2011 |location=London}}</ref> President [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] responded to the allegations by telling his ministers to take their holidays in France more often, saying "What was commonplace a few years back can prove shocking nowadays."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/02/20112917101935120.html |title=Sarkozy bid to end holiday furore â Europe |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Georgia}} â The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Georgia)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] urged its citizens to get out of Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.gov.ge/index.php?lang_id=ENG&sec_id=30&info_id=13355 |title=Information on the setting up of hotline in connection with the recent developments in Egypt|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Georgia|date= 30 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Germany}} â Foreign Minister [[Guido Westerwelle]] said he was "very concerned" and called on all involved to show restraint.<ref>{{cite web|author=Al-Shalchi, Adeel|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/211587/egypt-protesters-clash-for-2nd-day-with-police |title=Egypt Protesters Clash for 2nd Day with Police |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[GMA News and Public Affairs]]'')|date=27 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Later [[Angela Merkel]] called upon all involved, and especially the Egyptian government and the president, to allow peaceful demonstrations, to give freedom of opinion a chance. "We have to come to a peaceful dialogue in Egypt because the stability of the country is of extraordinary importance."<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12316019 |title=In Quotes: Reaction to Egypt Protests |work=[[BBC News]] |date= 30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Greece}} â The Foreign Ministry said in a statement on 30 January that it plans to evacuate its citizens from Egypt.<ref name="Greece evacuate Egypt">{{cite news |url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/foreign-countries-evacuate-citizens-as-cairo-unrest-grows-377303.html |title=Foreign Countries Evacuate Citizens as Cairo Unrest Grows |last=Bladd |first=Joanne |work=[[Arabian Business]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Italy}} â Prime Minister [[Silvio Berlusconi]] said that he hoped for "continuity in the government" as Western leaders wanted a "more democratic system without ruptures with a president like Mubarak that all the Western hemisphere, including the U.S., had considered the wisest man and a reference point in all of the Middle East." He played down the scale of the protests by saying that there were "really few" demonstrators out of a population of 80 million.<ref>{{cite web|last=Krause |first=Flavia |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-04/berlusconi-says-west-considered-mubarak-wisest-man-in-mideast.html |title=Berlusconi Says West Considered Mubarak âWisest Manâ in Mideast |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2011-02-04 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> *: The Foreign Ministry gave a statement where they expressed deep regret over the civilian casualties. They urged the immediate cessation of every kind of violence, and called for respect for civil rights and for freedom of speech and communication, including the right to hold peaceful rallies. They pointed out that Egypt's stability is a priority for their country.<ref name="bbc.co.uk"/> * {{flag|Latvia}} â The Foreign Ministry of Affairs was concerned about the situation in Egypt, and advised their citizens not to travel to Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.gov.lv/en/news/press-releases/2011/january/28-2/ |title=Comment by Foreign Ministry Press Secretary on situation in Egypt |publisher=Mfa.gov.lv |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Macedonia}} â The Ministry of Foreign Affairs warned their citizens not to travel to Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.gov.mk/default1.aspx?ItemID=318&id=1123 |title=Mfa Warns Citizens Against Travelling To Egypt |publisher=Mfa.gov.mk |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Netherlands}} â The Minister of Foreign Affairs [[Uri Rosenthal]] called on "the Egyptian authorities to stop violence, allow the media for all the people and asks the international community to stay on one line to Egypt."<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=at minimum, needs english translation of dutch headline appended next to dutch headline}} {{cite web |url=http://nos.nl/audio/215039-minister-rosenthal-reageert-op-ontwikkelingen-egypte.html |title=Minister Rosenthal reageert op ontwikkelingen Egypte |work=[[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011 |language=[[Dutch language|Dutch]]}}</ref> * {{flag|Norway}} â Minister of Foreign Affairs [[Jonas Gahr StÃ¸re]] called on the Egyptian authorities to refrain from violence, allow peaceful protests, and respect basic political and economical rights. "I deeply regret that lives have been lost during these demonstrations. The right to free speech and to demonstrate are basic human rights and prerequisites for democratic development. The extensive demonstrations can be viewed as a sign that there are limits to political free speech in Egypt."<ref>{{cite news |title=The situation in Egypt |url=http://www.regjeringen.no/en/dep/ud/press/news/2011/situation_egypt.html?id=632131 |newspaper=Norwegian Government |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Poland}} â The Foreign Ministry expressed concern over the many civilian casualties, and called for respect for human rights.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.msz.gov.pl/Foreign,Ministry,statement,on,the,situation,in,Egypt,40688.html |title=Foreign Ministry statement on the situation in Egypt |publisher=Msz.gov.pl |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Portugal}} â The Foreign Ministry condemned the violence and urged its citizens in Egypt to leave the country.<ref>{{cite web|author=MinistÃ©rio dos NegÃ³cios Estrangeiros |url=http://www.mne.gov.pt/mne/en/noticiasen/201101301347.htm |title=Portuguese MFA about Egypt |publisher=Mne.gov.pt |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Russia}} â In a telephone conversation with Mubarak, [[Russian President|President]] [[Dmitry Medvedev]] expressed his hope that the situation would be resolved by peaceful and legal means. He expressed the importance of guaranteeing the security of the [[Embassy of Russia in Cairo]] and Russian citizens who are still located in the country.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eng.kremlin.ru/news/1722|title=Telephone conversation with President of Egypt Hosni Mubarak|date=3 January 2011|publisher=[[Presidential Press and Information Office]]|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> *: Foreign Minister [[Sergey Lavrov]] sent a message to his Egyptian counterpart expressing concerns over the current situation and compassion with the people of Egypt. He expressed hope that the Egyptian government would stabilise the situation, stating that "the stability of Egypt meets the genuine interests of both the Egyptians and the entire Middle East region." He hoped that "the Egyptian side will take comprehensive measures to ensure the safety of Russian citizens located in Egypt."<ref>[http://www.mid.ru/brp_4.nsf/0/28DA98369E67F581C3257827005664EC About the message from Minister of Foreign Affairs of Russia Sergey Lavrov to Minister of Foreign Affairs of Egypt Ahmed Aboul Gheit] (in [[Russian language|Russian]]).</ref> [[File:2011 Egypt protests - Madrid solidarity protest children.jpg|thumb|Solidarity protest at the Egyptian embassy in [[Madrid]], 30 January]] * {{flag|Slovakia}} â The Foreign Ministry condemned the violence and use of force against the protests. Slovak Minister of Foreign Affairs said that Egypt has to respect human rights and civic liberties.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foreign.gov.sk/servlet/content?MT=/App/WCM/main.nsf/vw_ByID/ID_C0B1D004B5A332B2C1257627003301E7_EN&OpenDocument=Y&LANG=EN&TG=BlankMaster&URL=/App/WCM/Aktualit.nsf/(vw_ByID)/ID_205986550CAB3CE2C125782A002FC618 |title=Slovak MFA declaration on the situation in Egypt |publisher=Foreign.gov.sk |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Spain}} â Foreign Minister [[Trinidad Jimenez]] said that the EU supports the "people who are in the street". "We support the claiming in the street for more reforms and more rights".<ref>[[Staff writer]] (31 January 2011). [http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/01/2011131192145725920.html%20Europe "US Envoy Meets ElBaradei â Ex-Ambassador, Who Is in Cairo To Reinforce US Message to Mubarak Government, Has Held Talks with Opposition Figure"]. ''[[Al Jazeera English]]''. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref> * {{flag|Sweden}} â Swedish Prime Minister [[Fredrik Reinfeldt]] stated in an interview that he hopes for an eventual democratic Egypt but fears what might happen instead, saying that a reformed Egypt with a harsher attitude towards Israel would be very destabilising for the region.<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=at minimum, needs english translation of swedish headline appended next to swedish headline}} {{cite web|author=Benigh, Love|url=http://svt.se/2.22584/1.2313784/reinfeldt_forsvarar_forsiktig_linje|title=Ãndrade villkor fÃ¶r etanolbilar|language=[[Swedish language|Swedish]]|work=[[Sveriges Television]]|date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> *: Foreign Minister [[Carl Bildt]] criticised Egypt for blocking the internet, comparing it to [[Myanmar]] in 2007. "In the long run, free access to information is better for confidence and stability than restrictions and prohibitions. Measures such as this that aim at short-term stability may very well lead to more long-term suppression."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.regeringen.se/sb/d/7967/a/159996 |title=Foreign Minister Carl Bildt on the events in Egypt |publisher=regeringen.se |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Switzerland}} â [[President of the Swiss Confederation|Swiss Conferation President]] and [[Federal Department of Foreign Affairs|Foreign Affairs Minister]] [[Micheline Calmy-Rey]] said she was "worried about the increasing violence in Egypt". She called on the Egyptian government to "respect freedom of speech and of assembly".<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.tsr.ch/info/monde/2926479-egypte-les-manifestations-repartent-de-plus-belle.html |title=''Egypte: Moubarak nomme un vice-prÃ©sident''|trans_title=Egypt: Mubarak Names a Vice President|language=[[French language|French]]|work=[[TÃ©lÃ©vision Suisse Romande]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> *: Finance Minister [[Eveline Widmer-Schlumpf]] said that the [[government of Switzerland]] was examining whether Mubarak had any assets in the country. "The Federal Department of Foreign Affairs is looking into [any assets in Swiss banks]".<ref>{{cite web|last=Baldwin |first=Leigh |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-08/switzerland-is-examining-whether-mubarak-has-assets-in-country.html |title=Switzerland Is Examining Whether Mubarak Has Financial Assets in Country |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|Turkey}} â [[Prime Minister of Turkey|Turkish Prime Minister]] [[Recep Tayyip ErdoÄan]] was the first leader in [[Europe]] and the [[Middle East]] to call for Mubarak to heed the peopleâs demands and leave his post to pave the way for a more democratic regime,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=erdogan-proud-of-his-stance-against-mubarak-slams-opposition-2011-02-15 |title=Turkish PM proud of stance against Mubarak, slams opposition |work=Hurriyet Daily News |date=15 February 2011 |accessdate=17 February 2011}}</ref> saying the era of governments surviving through repression was over.<ref>{{cite web |author=Harvey, Benjamin|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/erdogan-tells-egypt-s-mubarak-he-should-listen-to-his-people.html |title=Erdogan Tells Egypt's Mubarak He Should Listen to His People |work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> "No government can survive against the will of its people", ErdoÄan said in a televised address to members of the ruling [[AK Party]], which was broadcast live by some Arabic TV channels, including ''Al Jazeera''. "Listen to [the] people's outcry and humanistic demands. Meet people's demand for change without any hesitation. I would like to make it clear here. You should take the first step for peace, security and stability of Egypt without giving any chance for exploiters, evil circles and those who have dark scenarios on Egypt. You should take steps that could satisfy the people." He called for anti-government protesters to refrain from violence and protect the country's cultural heritage. "Everyone has the right to fight for freedom, but without violence."<ref>{{cite web |author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121115128839350.html |title=Turkish PM Backs Egypt Protesters â Erdogan Urges Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak To 'Lend an Ear to the People's Cries' and Herald a New Era of Reform |work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=1 February 2011 |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> *: Foreign Minister [[Ahmet DavutoÄlu]] said that "there can be demands of communities and they can be expressed. These demands are justified. Transparency and accountability are accepted values in the international community. If these demands are brought on the agenda, in this context, they should be understood right by those countries and by governments there."<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=at minimum, needs english translation of turkish headline in "trans_title" field}} {{cite web|url=http://www.milliyet.com.tr/davutoglu-bunlar-hakli-taleplerdir/dunya/haberdetay/30.01.2011/1345927/default.htm |title=DavutoÄlu: Bunlar haklÄ± taleplerdir |trans_title= |work=[[Milliyet]]|language=[[Turkish language|Turkish]]|date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> **On 15 February ErdoÄan called for an international donor conference to help Egypt overcome its economic woes. Erdogan, who spoke by phone with US President Barack Obama on 12 February, said Obama embraced the idea.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-02/16/c_13733622.htm |title=Turkish PM calls for int'l donor meeting for Egypt |work=Xinhua |date=16 February 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|United Kingdom}} â On 2 February Prime Minister [[David Cameron]] called for an end to the violence, describing the scenes in Cairo as "despicable" and said they should not be repeated. He said, "We have been watching the events in Cairo with grave concern, and completely condemn the violence that is taking place. And if it turns out that the regime, in any way, has been sponsoring or tolerating this violence, that would be completely and utterly unacceptable. These are despicable scenes that we are seeing and they should not be repeated. They underline the need for political reform and, frankly, for that political reform to be accelerated and to happen quickly. We need to see a clear roadmap for that political reform, so that people in Egypt can have confidence that their aspirations for a more democratic, a future with greater rights, is met. And that change needs to start happening now, and the violence needs to stop."<ref>[[Press release]] (2 February 2011). [http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/news/latest-news/?view=News&id=543389682 "Prime Minister Condemns Violence in Egypt"]. [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]] ([[United Kingdom]]). Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref> *: Foreign Secretary [[William Hague]] called on the authorities and protesters in Egypt to show restraint and avoid violence. He urged the Egyptian authorities to "listen to the concerns" of demonstrators.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Press release]]|url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/news/latest-news/?view=News&id=539828682 |title=Foreign Secretary on Protests in Egypt |publisher=[[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]] ([[United Kingdom]])|date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> ** Former Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] called Mubarak a "force for good."<ref name="bloombergreactions">Ali, Tariq ([[essay]]) (3 February 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-04/egypt-chaos-defines-bleeding-in-despot-arab-world-commentary-by-tariq-ali.html "Egypt Chaos Defines Bleeding in Despot Arab World: Tariq Ali"]. ''[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 5 February 2011.</ref>
; Joint statements A joint statement by [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|British Prime Minister]] [[David Cameron]], [[President of France|French President]] [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] and [[Chancellor of Germany|German Chancellor]] [[Angela Merkel]] read: {{Quotation| "We are deeply concerned about the events that we are witnessing in Egypt. We recognise the moderating role President Mubarak has played over many years in the Middle East. We now urge him to show the same moderation in addressing the current situation in Egypt...It is essential that the further political, economic and social reforms President Mubarak has promised are implemented fully and quickly and meet the aspirations of the Egyptian people.The Egyptian people have legitimate grievances and a longing for a just and better future. We urge President Mubarak to embark on a process of transformation which should be reflected in a broad-based government and in free and fair elections"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.number10.gov.uk/latest-news/2011/01/joint-uk-france-germany-statement-on-egypt-59740 |title=Joint UK-France-Germany statement on Egypt |publisher=Number10.gov.uk |date= |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>}}
On 3 February the three were joined by [[Prime Minister of Italy|Italian Prime Minister]] [[Silvio Berlusconi]] and [[Prime Minister of Spain|Spanish Prime Minister]] [[Jose Luis Zapatero]] in issuing another statement: "Only a quick and orderly transition to a broad-based government will make it possible to overcome the challenges Egypt is now facing. That transition process must start now."<ref>{{cite web|author=Buckle, Eddie|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-03/european-leaders-demand-immediate-regime-change-amid-violence-in-egypt.html|title=Sarkozy, Merkel, Cameron Make Joint Call for Immediate Egypt Regime Change|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=3 February 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|Ukraine}} â On 10 February former [[Prime Minister of Ukraine]] [[Yulia Tymoshenko]] said that Egypt can learn from the [[Orange Revolution]] about how to amend the constitution to establish a civil society after a peaceful revolution, and not repeat the mistakes of Ukraine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/opinion/2011/02/201126142032991448.html |title=My revolution betrayed |publisher=Aljazeera |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>
==Oceania== [[File:Egypt Uprising solidarity Melbourne protest, 4 February 2011.jpg|thumb|right|Solidarity protest in [[Melbourne]], Australia]] <!--3 February 2011- contrary to norm, put temporary spacers between countries for easier editing; can be removed after article is more finessed--> * {{flag|Australia}} â On 3 February, [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]] [[Julia Gillard]] announced "the time for change has come" and that "I absolutely condemn this violence."<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Prime Minister Julia Gillard calls for Egypt President Hosni Mubarak to stand down now|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/world/mubarak-supporters-clash-with-egyptian-opposition-protesters/story-e6frev00-1225999171589|date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flag|New Zealand}} â On 5 February [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (New Zealand)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Murray McCully]] condemned the violence against the protesters and expressed concern over the targeting of foreign journalists. "Reports that foreign journalists, including New Zealanders, have been targeted is extremely concerning and directly violates fundamental freedoms."<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Press release]]|title=McCully Condemns Violence Against Journalists in Egypt|url=http://feeds.beehive.govt.nz/release/mccully-condemns-violence-against-journalists-egypt?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+beehive-govt-nz%2Fportfolio%2Fforeign-affairs+%28Foreign+Affairs+-+beehive.govt.nz%29|publisher=[[Government of New Zealand]]|accessdate=5 February 2011|work=|date=5 February 2011}}</ref>
==Solidarity protests== [[File:Egypt Uprising solidarity Melbourne protest, 30 January 2011 009.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Solidarity protest at the Egyptian consulate in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]], 30 January]] Protests were held at the Egyptian embassy in [[Tunis]] in solidarity and in hope that the two countries' "revolutions" would spark a chain of events around the Arab world. Tunisia's [[Progressive Democratic Party]] said that Egypt had "called in the hour of change for an end to injustice and dictatorship. The Egyptian people supported the Tunisian people's revolution. Our heart is with you and our voices never cease to pray for victory." There was a demonstration outside the Egyptian embassy in [[Doha]], [[Qatar]].<ref name="protests"/> There were protests in Lebanon warning of the spread of the protests.<ref>{{cite web|author= Piven, Ben |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/features/2011/01/201112920129971160.html |title=The Domino Effect: Pan-Arab Unrest â Interactive of Anti-Government Protests from Tunisia to Egypt, Yemen and Jordan, with Pro-Western Regimes under Threat|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> On 25 January a march held in [[Gaza]] in solidarity with the protests was suppressed by Hamas. Police officers dressed in civilian clothing arrested six women and detained some 20 others, according to [[Human Rights Watch]].<ref>Issacharoff, Avi (2 February 2011). [http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/hamas-worried-upheaval-in-arab-world-will-spill-into-gaza-1.340690 "Hamas Worried Upheaval in Arab World Will Spill into Gaza â Gaza Police Disperse Rally Showing Solidarity with Egyptian Protesters; Several Thousand Join Facebook Group Calling for a Protest Against Hamas Rule in the Strip"]. ''[[Haaretz]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref>
In Syria a peaceful demonstration was held on 29 January in front of the Egyptian embassy in Damascus to protest against the killing of protesters by Egyptian police. Syrian security forces were deployed around the embassy and blocked demonstrators from reaching it.<ref>{{dead link|date=January 2011|reason=link provided is to dynamic page (in arabic with english portal link offered). will requires some research to fish intended article.}} {{cite web |url=http://www.metransparent.com/spip.php?page=article&id_article=12661&lang=ar |title=Ø§ÙÙ ÙØªØ­Ø± Ø§ÙØ³ÙØ±Ù ÙÙ "Ø­Ø³Ù Ø¹ÙÙ Ø¹ÙÙØ©": Ø¯Ù Ø´Ù Ø­Ø¸Ø±Øª Ù Ø¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø© ÙØ¯Ø¹Ù Ù ØµØ± " |translation=Syrian Security Forces Block Demonstrators from Reaching the Egyptian Embassy|date=30 January 2011|work=[[Middle East Transparent]]}}</ref> [[Arab Israeli]]s held rallies in solidarity with the Egyptian protesters.<ref>{{cite news|author=Raved, Ahiya|date=29 January 2011|title=Arab Israelis Back Egyptian Protestors â Protests Held Across Nation; Former MK Makhoul: We're Showing Solidarity with Arab Nations|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4020862,00.html|work=[[Ynetnews]]|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
On 28 January between 200 and 400 protesters held demonstrations outside the [[Fatih Mosque]] (where political activism has become more common since the [[Gaza flotilla raid]]) after the Friday prayer in Istanbul. A small leftist group gathered outside the Egyptian embassy in [[Ankara]], Turkey.<ref name="protests"/><ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.apimages.com/OneUp.aspx?st=det&ids=Turkey%20Egypt&showact=details&sort=date&prds=10135&intv=3d&sh=101&kwstyle=or&adte=1296393346&pagez=60&cfasstyle=AND&rids=7953b8aaa25a48829bddc873c33390a9&dbm=PThirtyDay&page=1&xslt=1 |title=Turkey Egypt |agency=Associated Press |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> Iranian students gathered in front of the Egypt's Interest Section{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=which embassy?}} in [[Tehran]] on 30 January to support the uprisings in Egypt. According to IRNA,{{who|date=February 2011|reason=what is this? no easily found wiki article}} the students, shouting slogans such as "Down with US, Down with Israel, Down with UK and down with Hosni Mubarak," condemned the Egyptian government's measures to confront protesters. The students demanded that the Iranian government shut down Egypt's Interest Section in Iran.<ref>[[Staff writer]] (30 January 2011). [http://english.irib.ir/news/political/item/70539-iranian-students-condemn-egyptian-police-measures-against-protesters "Iranian Students Condemn Egyptian Police Measures Against Protesters"]. ''[[Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting]]''. Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref>
On 28 January [[Egyptian Canadian|Egyptians living in Canada]] and others gathered at the embassy in Ottawa as well as the consulate in [[Montreal]]. The next day, Canadians in [[Toronto]], [[Montreal]], [[Vancouver]], and other cities peacefully demonstrated in support of the uprising, criticising the Canadian government's cautious and generic response.<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Demonstrators Across Canada Rally in Support of Egyptian Protesters|url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/hundreds-of-canadians-rally-in-support-of-egyptian-protesters/article1887588/|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|accessdate=31 January 2010|date=29 January 2010|location=Toronto}}</ref> On 29 January in [[Dearborn, Michigan]], 300 people expressed their solidarity for the Egyptian people.<ref>{{cite web|author=Steele, Micki|url=http://detnews.com/article/20110129/METRO/101290382/Protesters-rally-in-Dearborn-to-support-Egyptian-people |title=Protesters Rally in Dearborn To Support Egyptian People |work=[[The Detroit News]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> Around 150 protesters demonstrated in solidarity with the Egyptian people in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Choudhury, Atif|url=http://www.vanderbiltorbis.com/?p=164 |title=Nashville rallies in support of protests in Egypt, Tunisia |work=[[Vanderbilt Orbis]] |date=19 February 2011 |accessdate=19 February 2011}}</ref>
[[File:NYC Rally for Egyptian Democracy Protestors, 29 January 2011 008.jpg|thumb|Solidarity protest in [[New York City]], 29 January]] The Egyptian embassy in Venezuela was temporarily taken over by Venezuelans of Egyptian descent,<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110128-715552.html|publisher=''[[Dow Jones]]'' (via ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'')|title=Egypt Embassy In Venezuela Sees Shortlived Protest â Chavez|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> an action which was condemned by President [[Hugo Chavez]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Mardones, Carolina |url=http://www.panorama.com.ve/29-01-2011/avances/embajada-caracas.html |title=Manifestantes toman temporalmente embajada de Egipto en Caracas|translation=Protesters temporarily take Egyptian Embassy in Caracas |language=[[Spanish language|Spanish]]|work=panorama.com.ve |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
Egyptians in Ireland and members of the [[Irish Anti-War Movement]] held a protest outside the embassy in Dublin on 28 January to "show solidarity for the people in Egypt to say to them that we are behind you and we support you."<ref>Bray, Allison (29 January 2011). [http://www.independent.ie/world-news/africa/protesters-demand-justice-and-democracy-at-embassy-demo-2516024.html "Protesters Demand Justice and Democracy at Embassy Demo"]. ''[[Irish Independent]]''. Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref>
In London, fifty protesters outside the Egyptian embassy called for Mubarak's regime to resign.<ref name="protests">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2011/01/201112815843772129.html |title=Egypt Supporters Rally Worldwide â Protests Held Across Globe in a Show of Solidarity with Egyptian Demonstrators Attempting To Oust President|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> In [[Frankfurt]], [[Germany]], a small group protested on 29 January in the main pedestrian zone, the [[Zeil]], to show their support for the Egyptian people. In [[Munich]], Germans joined the Egyptians in a demonstration in [[Odeonsplatz]] asking Mubarak to leave.{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} In [[The Hague]], [[The Netherlands]], 200 people protested in front of the [[Peace Palace]] against the regime of Mubarak.<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=at minimum, needs english translation of dutch headline appended next to dutch headline}} [[Staff writer]] (30 January 2011). [http://nos.nl/artikel/215312-reisbureaus-halen-toeristen-weg-chaos-op-vliegveld.html "Reisbureaus halen toeristen weg, chaos op vliegveld"] (in [[Dutch language|Dutch]]). ''[[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting]]''. Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref>
on 31 January in India's prestigious [http://www.jnu.ac.in/ Jawaharlal Nehru University]Egypt Solidarity Forum ([http://esfdelhi.blogspot.com ESF])organized a solidarity march in which some 500 students and faculty members participated.<ref name=anas>{{cite news|last=Gazette|first=Milli|title=India supports Egyptian peopleâs struggle|url=http://www.milligazette.com/news/601-india-supports-egyptian-peoples-struggle|accessdate=11 November 2011|newspaper=Milli Gazette|date=16-28 February 2010}}</ref> The march was addressed by Professor A K Ramakrishnan, a distinguished faculty of School of International Studies at the university. Convener of the solidarity forum Omair Anas told that âWe believe that Egyptian people are victims of their own rulers as well as their Western masters. Hosni Mubarak has protected interests of capitalists, multinationals and his Western masters, mainly the United States.<ref name=anas>{{cite web|last=TCN News|title=Delhi students hold solidarity march for Egyptian protesters|url=http://twocircles.net/node/237444|publisher=Two Cirlce|accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> On the next day, Forum called to join mass demonstration at Embassy of Egypt in New Delhi where thousands of students from different student organizations joined the demonstrated against the Mubarak regime and some protesters including convener of the Egypt Solidarity Forum were detained by the Delhi Police.<ref name=anas>{{cite news|last=Gilani|first=Iftekhar|title=Egyptian crises brings Leftists and Islamists together|url=http://www.tehelka.com/story_main48.asp?filename=Ws020211INTERNATIONAL.asp|accessdate=11 November 2011|newspaper=Tehelka|date=2 February 2010}}</ref> Egypt Solidarity Forum had also launched a Facebook campaign<ref name=anas>{{cite web|title=Arab Solidarity Forum|url=http://www.facebook.com/groups/151670754888053/|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=11 November 2011}}</ref> and an online petition to support Casablanca call for political reform was also launched.
In [[South Africa]], on 4 February, approximately 300 demonstrators blocked Bourke Street, the location of the Egyptian embassy in [[Pretoria]],<ref>[[Department of International Relations and Cooperation]] (South Africa). [http://www.dfa.gov.za/foreign/forrep/fore.htm#egy "Foreign Representatives in South Africa"]. Retrieved 10 February 2011.</ref> in peaceful protests organised by South African trade unions, human rights groups, and Egyptians in South Africa. The demonstrators shouted slogans such as "out with Mubarak" in English, [[Afrikaans]], [[Zulu language|Zulu]], and [[Arabic language|Arabic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/02/04/s-africans-rally-support-egypt-protesters/ |title=S. Africans rally to support Egypt protesters |publisher=FoxNews.com |date=2010-02-01 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref>
On 9 February in [[Ukraine]], [[FEMEN]] activists organised a topless protest<ref>[http://femen.livejournal.com/136430.html FEMEN Livejournal, photos]</ref> in front of the Egyptian embassy in [[Kiev]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8144289-topless-femen-activist-supports-the-egyptian-revolution-at-the-egyptian-embassy-in-kiev-photos|title=Topless FEMEN activist Supports the Egyptian Revolution in kiev|date=9 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
==Non-governmental organisations== * The [[AFL-CIO]] supported the protests, saying that US President Barack Obama was not "on their side."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.defenddemocracy.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=11792097&Itemid=348 |title=AFL-CIO Backs Egyptian Worker Protests, Says Obama Policies Not Clearly 'On Their Side' |publisher=Defenddemocracy.org |date= |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> * [[Salil Shetty]], head of [[Amnesty International]], believed Hosni Mubarak's decision to fire his cabinet would not stop the anti-government protests.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=205730 |title=Amnesty Int'l: Egypt Cabinet Firing Won't Quell Protests |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'') |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=3 February 2011}}<!--at late jan/early feb 2011, this particular link to jpost.com can be VERY slow to load. other jpost.com links load regulary.--></ref> * [[Hacktivist]] group [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] attacked multiple government websites and issued press releases calling for support of the Egyptian people.<ref>{{cite news|last=Emspak|first=Jesse|title=Egyptian Gov't Web Sites Under Attack|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/105329/20110126/egyptian-government-web-sites-attacked.htm|accessdate=27 January 2011|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=26 January 2011}}</ref> * Mohamed Abdel Dayem of the [[Committee to Protect Journalists]] condemned police violence against journalists.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://cpj.org/2011/01/journalists-beaten-websites-blocked-amid-protests.php|title=Journalists Beaten, Websites Blocked Amid Protests in Egypt|publisher=[[Committee to Protect Journalists]]|date=26 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> * [[Human Rights Watch]] said Egyptian police had escalated the use of force against largely peaceful demonstrations and called it "wholly unacceptable and disproportionate".<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html |title=Fresh Protests Erupt in Egypt â Army Reportedly on the Streets of Cairo as Curfew Is Imposed from 6 pm to 7 am Local Time|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> * Militant Islamist group [[al-Qaeda]]'s Ayman al-Zawahiri said, "The constitution of the regime in Egypt claims that it is democratic. But it's truth that it's a suppressive regime that rules the people with suppressive forces and fake elections and corrupt media and unjust law."<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Matthew Cole]]|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/al-qaeda-message-egypt/story?id=12951313 |title=Newly Released Al Qaeda Message Blasts Mubarak |work=[[abc news]] |date=18 February 2011 |accessdate=18 February 2011}}</ref>
==Evacuations and travel advisories== * {{flag|Argentina}} â From 1 February until 4 February, the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Argentina)|Argentine Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] issued a series of press releases urging Argentine citizens not to visit Egypt "unless it is absolutely necessary, until the situation returns to normal".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cancilleria.gov.ar/portal/prensa/comunicado.php?buscar=5011 |title=Argentine Foreign Affairs Ministry Press Release, 1 Feb (in Spanish) |publisher=Cancilleria.gov.ar |date= |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cancilleria.gov.ar/portal/prensa/comunicado.php?buscar=5015 |title=Argentine Foreign Affairs Ministry Press Release, 2 Feb (in Spanish) |publisher=Cancilleria.gov.ar |date= |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cancilleria.gov.ar/portal/prensa/comunicado.php?buscar=5021 |title=Argentine Foreign Affairs Ministry Press Release, 4 Feb (in Spanish) |publisher=Cancilleria.gov.ar |date= |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flagcountry|Austria}} sent{{when|date=February 2011|reason=needs context}} two charter planes and one military plane to evacuate its nationals from Egypt, but many Austrians on holiday in seaside resorts want to stay.<ref name="eurovoice">[[Staff writer]] (1 February 2011). [http://www.europeanvoice.com/page/european-voice-blogs/366.aspx?blogitemid=737 "The Paper Clip, 1 February"]. ''The Paper Clip'' ([[blog]] of ''[[European Voice]]''). Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref> * {{flagcountry|Azerbaijan}} sent a special commercial [[Azerbaijan Airlines]] flight on 30 January to bring back its citizens, most of them students and embassy staff.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|date=31 January 2011|title=Plane with Azerbaijani Citizens Evacuated from Egypt Arrives in Baku (Update)|url=http://en.trend.az/news/incident/1820441.html|work=[[Trend News Agency]]|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Luscombe|first=Jane|title=Kiwis in Egypt Left Stranded by Govt|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Kiwis-in-Egypt-left-stranded-by-Govt/tabid/417/articleID/196599/Default.aspx|work=[[3 News]]|date=31 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> An employee of the Azerbaijani embassy in Egypt was killed in Cairo on the same day as a result of mass public disorder.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Azerbaijani Official Killed in Cairo|url=http://www.news.az/articles/politics/30543|publisher=''[[Azerbaijan Press Agency]]'' (via ''[[news.az]]'')|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|title=ÐÑÐ¸ Ð±ÐµÑÐ¿Ð¾ÑÑÐ´ÐºÐ°Ñ Ð² ÐÐ³Ð¸Ð¿ÑÐµ Ð¿Ð¾Ð³Ð¸Ð± ÑÐ¾ÑÑÑÐ´Ð½Ð¸Ðº Ð¿Ð¾ÑÐ¾Ð»ÑÑÑÐ²Ð° ÐÐ·ÐµÑÐ±Ð°Ð¹Ð´Ð¶Ð°Ð½Ð° â ÐÐÐÐÐÐÐÐÐ|translation=An employee of the Azerbaijani Embassy was killed in the Egyptian unrest|url=http://news.day.az/politics/250550.html|language=[[Russian language|Russian]]|work=[[day.az]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flagcountry|Australia}} The Prime Minister announced that a chartered jet would be available to evacuate Australian nationals, and that extra consular staff will be provided. Two Qantas [[Boeing 747|747]] flights from [[Cairo International Airport]] removed Australian citizens to Frankfurt on 2 February and 4 February at government expense. Since many people were unable to reach Cairo quickly, another flight from [[Luxor]] was considered.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smartraveller.gov.au/zw-cgi/view/TravelBulletins/egypt |title=Australian DFAT travel Bulletin |publisher=Smartraveller.gov.au |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flagcountry|Brazil}} The Brazilian embassy discouraged any trips to Egypt until the situation returns to normal and started evacuating Brazilians in the country.<ref name="MRE2">{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=at minimum, needs english translation of portuguese headline appended next to portuguese headline}} [http://www.itamaraty.gov.br/sala-de-imprensa/notas-a-imprensa/situacao-no-egito SituaÃ§Ã£o no Egito] (in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]). Ministry of External Relations of Brazil. Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref> * {{flagcountry|Brunei}} The Brunei government had evacuated all of their 97 citizens out of Egypt via Dubai on a specially chartered flight.<ref>{{cite news| author= Siti Hajar and Azim Karim |url=http://brudirect.com/index.php/2011020238877/First-Stories/emotional-welcome-for-bruneians-from-egypt.html |title= Emotional Welcome for Bruneians from Egypt |work= Brudirect.com (Brunei Darussalam)|date= 3 February 2011 | accessdate= 4 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flagcountry|Canada}} launched an evacuation plan to evacuate citizens from Egypt using [[Air Canada]] charter flights contracted by the [[Government of Canada]] to [[Frankfurt]], London, and Paris. Approximately 6,500 Canadian citizens in Egypt are expected to reimburse the cost of the plane tickets to Europe and self-arrange for an ongoing flight back to Canada.<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2011/01/30/egypt-evacuation-protests.html|title=Canadians Could Begin Leaving Egypt Monday |work=[[CBC News]] |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> Conflicting reports suggested that the government was willing to subsidise C$400 off ticket prices and organise flights out of the country. However, the government was unsure of how many citizens would take advantage of the offer. "The government is recommending that Canadians leave Egypt," Foreign Affairs Minister [[Lawrence Cannon]] announced. "... The situation is deteriorating, the situation is not under control."<ref>Martin, Patrick; Ibbitson, John (31 January 2011). [http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/first-stranded-canadians-ready-to-leave-cairo/article1888623/ "First Stranded Canadians Ready To Leave Cairo"]. ''[[The Globe and Mail]]''. Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref> * {{flagcountry|Cyprus}} was prepared to receive foreign citizens evacuated from Cairo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.pseka.net/index.php?module=article&id=11657|title=As with Lebanon, once again Cyprus is the HUB for evacuees from a hot spot (Egypt).|publisher=PSEKA|date= 1 February 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Cyprus It advised its citizens currently in Egypt to avoid areas where demonstrations were being staged.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.pseka.net/index.php?module=article&id=11656|title=Cypriots â Egypt â Advice.|publisher=PSEKA|date= 1 February 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> * {{flagcountry|Finland}} organised a 200-seater [[Finnair]] [[Airbus]] to evacuate the approximately 150 Finnish citizens living in Egypt. According to Foreign Minister Alexander Stubb, the greatest challenge was to gather all Finns into one place to be evacuated. Finland allowed nationals of other countries to take vacant seats on the evacuation flights.<ref>{{Clarify|date=February 2011|reason=at minimum, needs english translation of finnish headline appended next to finnish headline}} {{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.iltalehti.fi/ulkomaat/2011013113103593_ul.shtml |title=Suomi harkitsee pysyvÃ¤sti EgyptissÃ¤ asuvien evakuointia|language=[[Finnish language|Finnish]]|publisher=''[[Suomen Tietotoimisto]]'' (via ''[[Iltalehti]]'')|date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flagcountry|India}} sent a special commercial [[Air India]] flight on 30 January to bring back its citizens who wanted to return home. Some of the 3,600-odd Indians who live in Egypt had expressed an interest in returning.<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Special-AI-plane-to-bring-back-300-Indians-from-Egypt/articleshow/7391308.cms |title=Special AI Plane To Bring Back 300 Indians from Egypt |publisher=''[[Indo-Asian News Service]]'' (via ''[[The Times of India]]'') |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> * {{flagcountry|Indonesia}} called for the quick evacuation of all Indonesian citizens in Egypt, most of whom were studying at [[Al-Azhar University]], by charter flights from [[Garuda Indonesia]].{{citation needed|date=February 2011}} * {{flag|Ireland}} â The Department of Foreign Affairs said that as of 3 February it had "given assistance to approximately 400 Irish citizens [in Egypt]."<ref>[http://archive.merrionstreet.ie/index.php/2011/02/statement-on-egypt-by-department-of-foreign-affairs/ "Statement on Egypt by Department of Foreign Affairs"].</ref> * {{flagcountry|Serbia}} evacuated tourists and people who worked in Egypt with two flights.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radio5.co.rs/portal/moduli.php?naziv=Vesti&file=clanak&sid=80297 |title=Turisti Iz Srbije Danas Se VraÄaju Iz Egipta |publisher=RADIO 5 |date=31 January 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vesti-online.com/Stampano-izdanje/02-02-2011/Dnevnik/114403/Srbija-evakuise--radnike-iz-Egipta |title=Vesti online / Å tampano izdanje / 2 February 2011 / Dnevnik / Srbija evakuiÅ¡e radnike iz Egipta |publisher=Vesti-online.com |date= |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flagcountry|Iraq}} offered to transport its citizens in Egypt, many of whom fled as a result of the [[Iraq War|war]], back to [[Baghdad]] for free.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/01/30/iraq-offers-evacuate-citizens-living-egypt/ |title=Iraq offers to evacuate citizens living in Egypt |publisher=FoxNews.com |date=2010-02-01 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> The Foreign Ministry advised their citizens to stay away from places of tension and offered to evacuate their citizens with three military aircraft.<ref name="mofairaq">[[Press release]] (30 January 2011). [http://www.mofa.gov.iq/eng/articles/display.aspx?gid=1&id=9992 "Statement of Iraqi Foreign Ministry on Status of Iraqi Citizens in the Arab Republic of Egypt"]. Office of [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Iraq)|Iraq Ministry of Foreign Affairs]]. Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref>
* {{flagcountry|Ireland}} As of 3 February, the [[Department of Foreign Affairs (Ireland)|Irish Department of Foreign Affairs]] advised [[Ireland|Irish]] citizens to immediately leave Egypt and advised against travel to Egypt.<ref>[[Staff writer]] (3 February 2011). [http://www.dfa.ie/home/index.aspx?id=44979 "Situation in Egypt"]. [[Department of Foreign Affairs (Ireland)|Ireland Department of Foreign Affairs]]. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref>
* {{flagcountry|Israel}} advised its citizens to refrain from non-essential travel to Egypt.<ref name="israel evacuation"/> It later called on all its citizens holidaying in the Sinai to return home. [[Greece]] called for its citizens to be evacuated.<ref name="Greece evacuate Egypt"/>
* {{flagcountry|Kuwait}}: His Highness the [[Emir of Kuwait]] ordered the embassy to make sure all Kuwaiti citizens were brought back home free ,of cost and to make sure the embassy provides a hotel if needed. [[Kuwait Airways]] received orders from the Emir to send special flights to bring all Kuwaitis in Egypt back home. The Kuwaiti Ambassador to Egypt said that all Kuwaiti citizens are "safe, and enjoy good health."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mofa.gov.kw |title=MOFA Kuwait |publisher=Mofa.gov.kw |date= |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
Thousands of Saudi and Egyptian passengers were stranded at the Cairo, Jeddah and Riyadh airports.<ref>{{cite web|author=Fakkar, Galal|url=http://arabnews.com/saudiarabia/article245797.ece |title=Thousands of Saudi, Egyptian Passengers Stranded |work=[[ArabNews]] |date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> Turkey sent two aircraft to pick up its stranded citizens.<!--from tv-->
* {{flagcountry|Malaysia}} On 2 February the Malaysian government announced plan to evacuate its citizens. The plan, code-named "Operation Pyramid" (Malay: Operasi Piramid) was supported by three [[Royal Malaysian Air Force]] [[C-130 Hercules]] planes, a [[Royal Malaysian Navy]] auxiliary ship, which was stationed at [[Gulf of Aden]]. Malaysian flag carrier [[Malaysia Airlines]] and low-cost carrier [[AirAsia]] later announced their support of the evacuation mission and sent aircraft to Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|author=Vanar, Muguntan; Mazwin, Nik Anis; Majid, Embun; Kammed, K. Ashraf; Tariq, Qishin; Rahim, Rahimy; Kulasagaran, Priya|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/2/3/nation/7930045&sec=nation | title= AirAsia and MAS on Mercy Mission| work= [[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]| date= 3 February 2011| accessdate= 3 February 2011}}</ref> The first evacuees were expected to arrive on 4 February.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/2/3/nation/20110203141435&sec=nation |title=Egypt Crisis: Malaysian Evacuees Leave for Jeddah| work=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]]| date=3 February 2011| accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flagcountry|New Zealand}} On 31 January the [[government of New Zealand|New Zealand government]] warned its citizens to avoid all areas with protests.<ref>{{cite web|author=The Associated Press |url=http://www.1310news.com/news/world/article/176722--new-zealand-warns-of-risk-to-travellers-to-egypt-advises-citizens-to-stay-away-during-protests?ref=topic&name=City-Hall&title= |title=New Zealand warns of risk to travellers to Egypt, advises citizens to stay away during protests |publisher=1310News |date=2011-01-30 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref>
* {{flagcountry|Nigeria}} President [[Goodluck Jonathan]] recommended that all Nigerians evacuate from Egypt. Nigeria then dispatched a team to assist its citizens in leaving the country.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2011/02/nigeria-begins-evacuation-of-citizens-from-egypt/ |accessdate= 4 February 2010 |date= 2 February 2010 |work= [[Vanguard (Nigeria)|Vanguard]] |title= Nigeria Begins Evacuation of Citizens from Egypt |author= Akinboade, Laide }}</ref>
* {{flagcountry|Russia}}'s government created an emergency team within the Foreign Ministry to form a plan for evacuating 25,000 Russian nationals. It had earlier recommended that tourists stay in their hotels and not leave the guarded resort areas.<ref>[[Staff writer]] (29 January 2011). [http://en.rian.ru/russia/20110129/162368424.html "Russia's Lavrov Urges Measures To Protect Tourists in Egypt"]. ''[[RIA Novosti]]''. Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref> Two major Russian oil and gas companies, [[Lukoil]] and [[Novatek]], evacuated their staff from Egypt on 30 January.<ref>[[Staff writer]] (30 January 2011). [http://en.rian.ru/russia/20110130/162378531.html "Russia's LUKoil Oil Major, Novatek Gas Giant Evacuate Staff from Riots-Hit Egypt"]. ''[[RIA Novosti]]''. Retrieved 31 January 2011.</ref>
* {{flagcountry|Kosovo}}{{ref label|status|a|}} The Kosovo Foreign Ministry urged Kosovars to leave Egypt. In the absence of diplomatic relations between the two states, citizens in distress were instructed to seek help from the Turkish embassy.<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=headline in foreign language. at minimum, needs english translation of foreign-language headline appended next to foreign-language headline}} {{cite web|url=http://www.mfa-ks.net/?page=1,4,628 |title=Fillon evakuimi i shtetasve tanÃ« nga Egjiptit |publisher=mfa.ks.net |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> The chairman of the [[New Kosovo Alliance]] [[Behgjet Pacolli]] organised flights back to Kosovo for some 160-odd Kosovas at his own expense.<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=headline in foreign language, at minimum needs english translation of foreign-language headline appended next to foreign-language headline}} {{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.telegrafi.com/?id=2&a=12721 |title=Pacolli fillon evakuimin e kosovarÃ«ve nga Egjipti |work=[[telegrafi.com]] |date=3 February 2011 |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flagcountry|Slovakia}} On 3 February a Slovak government aircraft brought 34 Slovaks, eight Czechs, one Hungarian, and two Portuguese citizens, who were living and working in Cairo and [[Hurghada]], to Slovakia.<ref>{{cite web|author=VilikovskÃ¡, Zuzana|url=http://spectator.sme.sk/articles/view/41540/10/forty_five_people_brought_to_slovakia_from_egypt_by_government_aircraft.html |title=Forty-Five People Brought to Slovakia from Egypt by Government Aircraft |work=[[The Slovak Spectator]]|date=4 February 2011 |accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flagcountry|South Korea}}'s flag carrier, [[Korean Air]], suspended flights to Egypt on 30 January. The Foreign Ministry suspended classes at the Korean School, which had an attendance of some forty elementary school students. The South Korean embassy put together an emergency plan to evacuate Korean nationals in the event of a serious crisis.<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2011/01/30/25/0301000000AEN20110130002500315F.HTML|title=Korean Air Suspends Flights to Cairo Amid Egypt Protests|work=[[Yonhap]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
* {{flagcountry|UK}} Until 30 January, the British government had advised its citizens to stay put (although advising against non-essential travel). However, the advice was then revised to say "We recommend that British nationals without a pressing need to be in Cairo, Alexandria or Suez leave by commercial means, where it is safe to do so." The Foreign Ministry recommendation that citizens in other parts of the country not affected by widespread protests and violence stay where they are and stay indoors.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/travel-and-living-abroad/travel-advice-by-country/middle-east-north-africa/egypt/ |title= Middle East and North Africa â Egypt|publisher=[[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]] ([[United Kingdom]])|date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
* {{flagcountry|USA}} The US advised its citizens to take evacuation flights to safe havens in Europe.<ref>{{cite news|last=Weaver |first=Matthew |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/jan/30/egypt-protests-live-updates |title=''The Guardian'' Live Update 10:38 am and 10:14 am |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011 |location=London}}</ref> It later warned its citizens to leave "as soon as possible".<ref>{{cite news |author=Gaouette, Nicole|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/clinton-visits-haiti-beset-by-undecided-election-delayed-earthquake-aid.html |title=Clinton Visits Haiti Beset by Undecided Election, Delayed Earthquake Aid |work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> It offered to send a plane to evacuate embassy personnel to reduce its "diplomatic footprint" in the country.<!--from tv-->{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}}
; Others [[Multinational corporation]]s said they would evacuate their employees.<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/30/egypt.evacuations/ |title=Foreign Governments, Businesses Begin Evacuations from Egypt |work=[[CNN]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
==Media and individuals== ===Media=== {{Expand section|date=February 2011}} Austria's ''[[Der Standard]]'' said that "the EU has failed to manage its response to the events in Egypt."<ref name="eurovoice"/>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=needs context. when did editorial appear? also, this is not quoting "der standard"; rather, it is quoting "the paper clip" blog of "european voices" paraphrasing what "der standard" said. would be better with direct source to der standard"}}<ref>{{de}} Prantner, Christoph ; Printausgabe, 1.2.2011 [http://derstandard.at/1295571276077/Vergeudeter-Kairo-Moment "Vergeudeter "Kairo-Moment"]. ''[[Der Standart]]''. Retrieved 6 February 2011.</ref>
''[[New York Times]]'' columnist [[Nicholas Kristof]] said that "it should be increasingly evident that Mr. Mubarak is not the remedy for instability in Egypt; he is its cause. The road to stability in Egypt requires Mr. Mubarak's departure, immediately."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.journalism.org/index_report/pej_news_coverage_index_january_31_february_6_2011 |title=Events in Egypt Trigger Record Coverage | Project for Excellence in Journalism (PEJ) |publisher=Journalism.org |date= |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> On 7 February, during the first show after a return from Egypt, [[CNN]] reporter [[Anderson Cooper]], who had twice been beaten by pro-Mubarak protesters, criticised the government on his nightly show. He said that Mubarak's regime has "blood on its hands" and is lying to the world about its actions. He called Egypt a police state and accused the government of saying "the direct opposite of what they have been doing." He cited the government's claim of reaching out to the opposition even though "his secret police were still arresting opposition figures." He further said that while the government has denied being involved in the violence directed at protesters, the military had been conspicuously slow to react to the targeting of demonstrators by pro-Mubarak forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/08/anderson-cooper-egypt-blood-hands-lies_n_820403.html |title=Anderson Cooper: Egyptian Government Has 'Blood On Their Hands,' Is Lying (VIDEO) |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref>
Writing for the ''[[Saturday Mirror]]'' on 6 August, former [[Nigeria]]n head of state [[Olusegun Obasanjo]] criticised the handling of the Mubaraks' trial and defended the deposed president. "I am not saying that Mubarak has not made a mistake in his almost thirty years in running the affairs of Egypt or that he has not committed any misdemeanour or offence, but decency demands that in bringing him to judgment, the good he has done should be brought side by side with the mistakes he has made and if this is done objectively, I am of the mind that the good will outweigh the mistakes," Obasanjo wrote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://saharareporters.com/news-page/olusegun-obasanjo-becomes-newspaper-columnist|publisher=Sahara Reporters|title=Olusegun Obasanjo Becomes A Newspaper Columnist!|date=11 August 2011|accessdate=11 August 2011}}</ref>
===Individuals=== [[MIT]] linguistics professor [[Noam Chomsky]] said that "[w]hatâs happening is absolutely spectacular. The courage and determination and commitment of the demonstrators is remarkable, and whatever happens these are moments that wonât be forgotten and are sure to have long-term consequences."<ref>[[Noam Chomsky|Chomsky, Noam]] (2 February 2011). [http://www.democracynow.org/2011/2/2/noam_chomsky_this_is_the_most "This Is the Most Remarkable Regional Uprising That I Can Remember"]. ''[[Democracy Now!]]''. (video report (requires [[Adobe Flash]]); link to "rush transcript" available). Retrieved 5 February 2011.</ref> He later added in an article in ''The Guardian'' that:<ref>[[Noam Chomsky|Chomsky, Noam]] ([[essay]]; 4 February 2011). [http://www.guardian.co.uk/commentisfree/cifamerica/2011/feb/04/radical-islam-united-states-independence "It's Not Radical Islam That Worries the US â It's IndependenceâThe Nature of Any Regime It Backs in the Arab World Is Secondary to ControlâSubjects Are Ignored Until They Break Their Chains"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. Retrieved 5 February 2011.</ref> <blockquote>Observers compared it to the toppling of Russian domains in 1989, but there are important differences. Crucially, no [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] exists among the great powers that support the Arab dictators. Rather, Washington and its allies keep to the well-established principle that democracy is acceptable only insofar as it conforms to strategic and economic objectives: fine in enemy territory (up to a point), but not in our backyard, please, unless properly tamed. One 1989 comparison has some validity: Romania, where Washington maintained its support for [[Nicolae Ceausescu]], the most vicious of the east European dictators, until the allegiance became untenable. Then Washington hailed his overthrow while the past was erased. That is a standard pattern: [[Ferdinand Marcos]], [[Jean-Claude Duvalier]], [[Chun Doo-hwan]], [[Suharto]] and many other useful gangsters. It may be under way in the case of Hosni Mubarak, along with routine efforts to try to ensure a successor regime will not veer far from the approved path.</blockquote>
[[Tariq Ali]] said the protests would be a "rude awakening for all those who imagined that the despots of the Arab world could be kept in place provided they continued to serve the needs of the West." He said that "while Western establishments lull themselves to sleep with fairy tales, ordinary citizens, who are defeated and demoralised, mull their revenge." He added that "If Tunisia was a tremor, the Egyptian uprising has become an earthquake that is spreading throughout the region. The generals in Cairo are still refusing to disperse the crowds with tanks and bullets. A full-scale Tiananmen Square option, which Mubarak and his friends would have appreciated, becomes difficult in these conditions."<ref name="bloombergreactions"/>
[[Ralph Nader]] said that Vice-President Omar Suleiman appeared to be making the decisions, if only to give the impression that Mubarak was relenting and would be willing to remain as a figurehead president until his term ends later in the year. He believes that Mubarak was very alert to what would be needed to maintain the loyalties of the police, the intelligence agencies, the security forces and the army and that when is forced out tens of thousands of those on his payroll would lose their patronage. Nader stated that "the government is striving to wait out the protesters, whose daily supplies and energies are being sapped by the overwhelming force arrayed against them to intimidate, weaken and keep their numbers down not just in [Tahrir] Square but also in other cities like Alexandria and Suez."<ref>{{cite web|last=Nader |first=Ralph |url=http://www.commondreams.org/view/2011/02/08-5 |title=Time for Democracy in Egypt |publisher=Common Dreams |date= |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref>
